chunks.text:
### Validity requirements for an application for entry clearance or settlement for an eligible Afghan citizen

1.   ARAP 1.1. An application for entry clearance or settlement as an eligible Afghan citizen must meet the following validity requirements: 
    1.   (a) the Ministry of Defence must have decided that the applicant meets the eligibility requirements in ARAP 3.1 to ARAP 3.6. and that ARAP 3.7. does not apply (the ARAP eligibility decision); and
    2.   (b) the Ministry of Defence must have made an application for entry clearance or settlement on the applicant’s behalf no more than 12 months after the ARAP eligibility decision was made; and
    3.   (c) the applicant must have provided biometrics when required; and
    4.   (d) the applicant must have provided a passport or other evidence which satisfactorily establishes their identity and nationality; and
    5.   (e) the applicant must be a citizen of Afghanistan; and
    6.   (f) the applicant must be aged 18 or over on the date of application.

ARAP 1.2. An application which does not meet all the validity requirements for ARAP may be rejected as invalid and not considered.
chunks.summary: Eligible Afghan citizens applying for entry clearance or settlement must satisfy criteria including a recent Ministry of Defence eligibility decision (within 12 months), provide biometrics and valid identity documents, and be aged 18 or over. Applications failing these conditions will be rejected as invalid.

chunks.text:
### Eligibility requirements for an eligible Afghan citizen

ARAP 3.1. To be an eligible Afghan citizen the applicant must have applied to, and received from, the Ministry of Defence a decision that the requirements under ARAP 3.2. to ARAP 3.6. are met and that ARAP 3.7. does not apply (“the ARAP eligibility decision”).

1.   ARAP 3.2. An eligible Afghan citizen is a person who: 
    1.   (a) is an Afghan citizen; and
    2.   (b) is aged 18 years or over; and
    3.   (c) meets the eligibility requirements in at least one of ARAP 3.3 to ARAP 3.6; and
    4.   (d) ARAP 3.7. must not apply.

1.   ARAP 3.3. A person meets the ARAP eligibility requirement if: 
    1.   (a) they submit an application to the Ministry of Defence on or after 1 April 2021 and before 15:00 BST on 01 July 2025; and
    2.   (b) at least one of the following eligibility requirements applies: 
        1.   (i) ARAP 3.4. (high and imminent risk of threat to life);
        2.   (ii) ARAP 3.5. (former employees eligible for relocation); and
        3.   (iii) ARAP 3.6. (special cases).

1.   ARAP 3.4. A person meets the eligibility requirement if: 
    1.   (a) they were at any time on or after 1 October 2001 directly employed in Afghanistan by a UK Government department; and
    2.   (b) because of that employment, there is a high and imminent risk of a threat to their life.

1.   ARAP 3.5. A person meets the eligibility requirements if: 
    1.   (a) at any time on or after 1 October 2001, the person: 
        1.   (i) was directly employed in Afghanistan by a UK Government department; or
        2.   (ii) provided linguistic services to or for the benefit of members of the UK’s armed forces in Afghanistan under contract to a UK Government department (whether as, or on behalf of, a party to the contract); and

    2.   (b) the nature of the role in which the person was employed was such that the UK’s operations in Afghanistan would have been materially less efficient or materially less successful if a role or roles of that nature had not been performed; and
    3.   (c) the nature of the role exposed the person to being publicly recognised as having performed that role; and
    4.   (d) as a result of that public recognition, the person’s safety is at risk.

1.   ARAP 3.6. A person meets the eligibility requirement if conditions 1 and 2 and one or both of conditions 3 and 4 applies: 
    1.   (a) Condition 1 is that at any time on or after 1 October 2001, the person: 
        1.   (i) was directly employed in Afghanistan by a UK Government department; or
        2.   (ii) provided goods or services in Afghanistan under contract to a UK Government department (whether as, or on behalf of, a party to the contract); or
        3.   (iii)worked in Afghanistan alongside a UK Government department, in partnership with or closely supporting and assisting that department.

    2.   (b) Condition 2 is that the person, in the course of the employment or work or the provision of those services under Condition 1, made a substantive and positive contribution towards the achievement of one or more of the following: 
        1.   (i) the UK Government’s military objectives with respect to Afghanistan; or
        2.   (ii) the UK Government’s national security objectives with respect to Afghanistan (and for these purposes, the UK Government’s national security objectives include counter-terrorism, counter-narcotics and anti-corruption objectives).

    3.   (c) Condition 3 is that because of the person’s employment or work or those services under Condition 1, the person: 
        1.   (i) is or was at an elevated risk of targeted attacks; and
        2.   (ii) is or was at high risk of death or serious injury.

    4.   (d) Condition 4 is that the person holds information, the disclosure of which would give rise to or aggravate a specific threat to a UK Government department or its interests.

1.   ARAP 3.7. A person does not meet the ARAP eligibility requirements, if either of the following apply: 
    1.   (a) the Ministry of Defence has withdrawn its eligibility decision; or
    2.   (b) the person was directly employed by, or contracted to, a UK Government department or unit and was dismissed from their job (except in circumstances where the Secretary of State considers that the person was dismissed for a minor reason).
chunks.summary: The provision applies to eligible Afghan citizens seeking relocation under ARAP, requiring them to obtain a decision from the Ministry of Defence confirming they meet specific eligibility criteria. Applicants must be Afghan, over 18, and satisfy at least one criteria, such as high risk due to employment or specific circumstances, with applications submitted between April 2021 and July 2025. Exceptions include individuals where ARAP 3.7. applies.

### Requirement for a Ministry of Defence decision on eligibility as an eligible Afghan citizen

ARAP 4.1. If the Ministry of Defence decision maker is satisfied the ARAP eligibility requirements are met, the Ministry of Defence will make an application for entry clearance or settlement on behalf of the applicant (otherwise the application to the Ministry of Defence will be refused).

chunks.text:
### Entry requirements for an eligible Afghan citizen

ARAP 5.1. A person seeking to come to the UK as an eligible Afghan citizen must have obtained entry clearance under the ARAP before they arrive in the UK.

ARAP 5.2. A person in the UK, applying for settlement as an eligible Afghan citizen must be in the UK on the date of application.

ARAP 5.3. A person applying for entry clearance as an eligible Afghan citizen must, if Appendix Tuberculosis applies, provide a valid medical certificate confirming that they have undergone screening for active pulmonary tuberculosis and that this tuberculosis is not present in them.
chunks.summary: Eligible Afghan citizens must obtain ARAP entry clearance before arriving in the UK or be in the UK at application for settlement; applicants must also provide TB screening results if applicable.

chunks.text:
### Decision on an application for entry clearance or settlement as an eligible Afghan citizen

ARAP 6.1. If the Home Office decision maker is satisfied that the eligibility and suitability requirements for entry clearance or settlement for an eligible Afghan citizen are met, the application will be granted, otherwise the application will be refused.

ARAP 6.2. An application for entry clearance or settlement as an eligible Afghan citizen will only be considered under this Appendix and will not be considered as an application for entry clearance, permission to stay or settlement on any other basis, including an application for leave outside of the Rules.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to eligible Afghan citizens applying for entry clearance or settlement under ARAP. The Home Office will grant the application if eligibility and suitability criteria are met; otherwise, it will be refused. Applications are only considered under this specific Appendix and not under other immigration routes.

chunks.text:
### Period of grant for an eligible Afghan citizen

ARAP 7.1. Where the applicant is outside the UK and the requirements for entry clearance are met, they will be granted entry clearance which will have effect on arrival in the UK as indefinite permission to enter (settlement).

ARAP 7.2. Where the applicant is in the UK and the requirements for settlement are met, they will be granted indefinite permission to stay (settlement).
chunks.summary: This provision applies to eligible Afghan citizens under ARAP. It grants indefinite leave to enter or stay in the UK upon meeting entry or settlement requirements, either outside or inside the UK. The key condition is fulfilling the specific ARAP criteria for settlement or entry clearance.

chunks.text:
### Validity requirements for entry clearance or settlement as a family member of an eligible Afghan citizen

1.   ARAP 8.1. An application for entry clearance or settlement as the family member of an eligible Afghan citizen must meet the following validity requirements: 
    1.   (a) the Ministry of Defence must have decided that the applicant meets the relevant ARAP eligibility requirements in ARAP 10.1 to ARAP 13.4 (the ARAP dependent eligibility decision); and
    2.   (b) an application must have been made by the Ministry of Defence on the applicant’s behalf for entry clearance or settlement no more than 12 months after an eligibility decision; and
    3.   (c) the applicant must have provided biometrics when required; and
    4.   (d) the applicant must have provided a passport or other evidence which satisfactorily establishes their identity and nationality; and
    5.   (e) the applicant must be a partner, child or eligible family member of a person who has been granted entry clearance or settlement as an eligible Afghan citizen, or of a person who is applying as an eligible Afghan citizen or their partner at the same time as the applicant.

ARAP 8.2. An application which does not meet all the validity requirements for ARAP is invalid may be rejected as invalid and not considered.
chunks.summary: Applicants under ARAP seeking entry clearance or settlement as a family member must have their eligibility confirmed by the Ministry of Defence within 12 months of the decision, provide biometrics and identification, and be a partner or child of an approved Afghan citizen. Non-compliance with these validity criteria results in automatic rejection.

chunks.text:
### Relationship requirements for a partner of an eligible Afghan citizen

ARAP 11.1. A person applying as a dependent partner of an eligible Afghan citizen must meet the requirements set out in Appendix Relationship with Partner.

ARAP 11.2. The applicant must be the dependent partner of an eligible Afghan citizen who the Ministry of Defence has decided is eligible for relocation to the UK under the ARAP.

ARAP 11.3. The applicant must have been the dependent partner of a person (P) on the date when the Ministry of Defence decided that P was an eligible Afghan citizen under the ARAP.

ARAP 11.4. If the relevant Afghan citizen has more than one partner, only one partner can apply for entry clearance or settlement in the UK under these Rules.
chunks.summary: Dependents applying under ARAP must be the partner of an eligible Afghan citizen approved for UK relocation, existing on the date of eligibility decision. Only one partner per Afghan citizen may apply, meeting the specific relationship requirements outlined in the rules.

chunks.text:
### Relationship requirements for a child of an eligible Afghan citizen

ARAP 12.1. The applicant must be under 18 on the date of application.

ARAP 12.2. The applicant must be the dependent child of an eligible Afghan citizen or their partner.

ARAP 12.3. The applicant must not be living an independent life.

1.   ARAP 12.4. The applicant must be applying at the same time as both of their parents are applying under ARAP unless: 
    1.   (a) the parent applying is the sole surviving parent; or
    2.   (b) the parent applying has sole responsibility for the child’s upbringing; or
    3.   (c) one parent is a British citizen or a person who has a right to enter or stay in the UK without restriction; and is or will be ordinarily resident in the UK; or
    4.   (d) the decision maker is satisfied that there are serious and compelling reasons to grant the application.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to children under 18 applying under ARAP as dependents of eligible Afghan citizens. They must be living with their parents, applying simultaneously unless specific exceptions like sole custody or UK residency apply. The applicant must not be independent and meet relationship and residency criteria.

metadata.section_title: Relationship requirement for an additional family member an eligible Afghan citizen

chunks.text:
### Relationship requirement for an additional family member an eligible Afghan citizen

ARAP 13.1. The applicant must be an additional family member of an eligible Afghan citizen or their partner.

ARAP 13.2. The additional family member cannot be an additional partner where one partner has applied for entry clearance or settlement under these Rules.

1.   ARAP 13.3. The additional family member must meet at least one of the following requirements: 
    1.   (a) as a result of the eligible Afghan citizen’s work for or with a UK Government department, the applicant must be at an elevated risk of targeted attacks, specific threats or intimidation; putting them at a high risk of death or serious injury; or
    2.   (b) the applicant must face specific vulnerabilities which have led to an exceptional level of family dependence, and would be unable, even with the practical and financial help of the eligible Afghan citizen or their partner, to obtain the required level of care or protection outside the UK either because it is not available, and there is no other person who can reasonably provide it, or because it is not affordable.

1.   ARAP 13.4. Where the additional family member is a child: 
    1.   (a) the eligible Afghan citizen or their partner must be a legal guardian of the child; or
    2.   (b) one parent is a British citizen or a person who has a right to enter or stay in the UK without restriction; and is or will be ordinarily resident in the UK; or
    3.   (c) the decision maker is satisfied that there are serious and compelling reasons to grant the applicant with the eligible Afghan citizen or their partner.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to additional family members of eligible Afghan citizens under ARAP. They must demonstrate a qualifying relationship and meet criteria related to being at elevated risk due to their connection to the Afghan citizen or face exceptional family dependence. Specific conditions for children include guardianship, parental nationality, or residence status.

chunks.text:
### Requirement for a Ministry of Defence ARAP dependent eligibility decision

ARAP 14.1. If the Ministry of Defence decision maker is satisfied all the relevant eligibility requirements for a dependant of an eligible Afghan citizen are met, the Ministry of Defence will submit an application for entry clearance or settlement on the applicant’s behalf.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to dependants of eligible Afghan citizens under the ARAP. The Ministry of Defence must confirm all eligibility criteria are met before submitting entry clearance or settlement applications on their behalf. No exceptions are specified.

chunks.text:
### Entry requirements for a family member of an eligible Afghan citizen

ARAP 15.1. A person seeking to come to the UK as the family member of an eligible Afghan citizen under the ARAP must have obtained entry clearance before they arrive in the UK.

ARAP 15.2. A person in the UK, applying for settlement as the family member of an eligible Afghan citizen, must be in the UK on the date of application.

ARAP 15.3. A person applying for entry clearance as the family member of an eligible Afghan citizen must, if Appendix Tuberculosis applies, provide a valid medical certificate confirming that they have undergone screening for active pulmonary tuberculosis and that this tuberculosis is not present in them.
chunks.summary: Family members of eligible Afghan citizens applying to enter or settle in the UK must obtain entry clearance before arrival or be in the UK at application time, with TB screening required if applicable.

chunks.text:
### Decision on an application for entry clearance or settlement as a family member of an eligible Afghan citizen

ARAP 16.1. If the Home Office decision maker is satisfied that all the suitability and eligibility requirements for a family member of an eligible Afghan citizen under the ARAP are met, the application will be granted, otherwise the application will be refused.

ARAP16.2. An application for entry clearance or settlement under ARAP will only be considered under this Appendix and will not be considered as an application for entry clearance, permission to stay or settlement on any other basis, including an application for leave outside the Rules.
chunks.summary: This provision applies to family members of eligible Afghan citizens applying under ARAP. The Home Office must satisfy that all suitability and eligibility requirements are met for approval; otherwise, the application will be refused. Applications are considered solely under ARAP and not on other immigration grounds.

chunks.text:
### Period of grant for a family member of an eligible Afghan citizen

ARAP 17.1. Where the requirements for entry clearance as the family member of an eligible Afghan citizen are met, they will be granted entry clearance, which will have effect on arrival in the UK as indefinite permission to enter (settlement).

ARAP 17.2. Where the requirements for settlement as the family member of an eligible Afghan citizen are met, they will be granted indefinite permission to stay (settlement).
